official-title.#text: To provide for the implementation of the property division regarding former Fort Wingate Depot Activity in McKinley County, New Mexico, and for other purposes.

sponsor.#text: Mr. Ben Ray Luján of New Mexico

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

short-title.#text: Fort Wingate Land Division Act of 2014

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: finds the following:

quote.#tail: ), ceased, and the installation was closed pursuant to

text.#text: In January 1993, the active mission of the Fort Wingate Depot Activity, located in McKinley County, New Mexico (in this Act referred to as

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: title II of the Defense Authorization Amendments and Base Closure and Realignment Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Defense Authorization Amendments and Base Closure and Realignment Act/t:II
usc/10/2687/note
public-law/100/526

text.#text: The lands occupied by the Former Fort Wingate Depot Activity were originally the ancestral lands of both the Zuni Tribe and the Navajo Nation, as indicated by tribal ancestral histories and the large number of archeological and cultural sites identified on the lands.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , with the support of the Zuni Tribe, the Navajo Nation, and other concerned parties, determined that, upon completion of environmental remediation of Former Fort Wingate Depot Activity, lands no longer needed by the Department of the Army would be transferred to the Secretary of the Interior and held in trust by the United States for the benefit of the Zuni Tribe and the Navajo Nation.

text.#text: The

On July 8, 2013, the Zuni Tribe and Navajo Nation, acting through their respective tribal leadership, who received authority from their tribal governments to enter into good faith discussions, and through their respective legal representatives, met in the Capitol office of Congressman Don Young, with Congressman Ben Ray Luján and Congressman Steve Pearce present, for final discussions to fairly divide Former Fort Wingate Depot Activity.

quote.#tail: prepared by the Army Corps of Engineers (in this Act referred to as the
quote.#text: Fort Wingate Depot Activity Negotiated Property Division July 2013

quote.#tail: ), and the land division outlined in section 3 was created in consultation with the Zuni Tribe and the Navajo Nation.

text.#text: In the resulting discussions, the tribal leaders informally agreed to the property divisions reflected in the map titled
This Act achieves the goal of fairly dividing Former Fort Wingate Depot Activity for the benefit of the Zuni Tribe and the Navajo Nation.

text.#text: Part 151 of title 25, Code of Federal Regulations, shall not apply to taking lands of Former Fort Wingate Depot Activity into trust under

header.#text: Retention of necessary easements and access

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall be subject to reservation by the United States of such easements as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: determines are reasonably required to permit access to lands of Former Fort Wingate Depot Activity for administrative, environmental cleanup, and environmental remediation purposes. The
shall provide to the governments of the Zuni Tribe and the Navajo Nation written copies of all easements reserved under this subsection.

text.#text: The lands of Former Fort Wingate Depot Activity held in trust or conveyed in restricted fee status pursuant to

In the case of the lands of Former Fort Wingate Depot Activity depicted as Parcel 1 on the Map, the lands shall be held in trust subject to a shared easement for cultural and religious purposes only. Both the Zuni Tribe and the Navajo Nation shall have unhindered access to their respective cultural and religious sites within Parcel 1. Within one year after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Zuni Tribe and the Navajo Nation shall exchange detailed information to document the existence of cultural and religious sites within Parcel 1 for the purpose of carrying out this paragraph. The information shall also be provided to the

header.#text: Parcel 1 Shared Cultural and religious Access

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: may facilitate shared access to other lands held in trust or restricted fee status pursuant to
, including, but not limited to, religious and cultural sites.

quote.#tail: on the Map, shall be held in common by both the Zuni Tribe and the Navajo Nation to provide for equal access to Former Fort Wingate Depot Activity.

text.#text: Nothing in this Act shall be construed as alleviating, altering, or affecting the responsibility of the United States for cleanup and remediation of Former Fort Wingate Depot Activity according to the terms previously agreed to by the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: activities on Former Fort Wingate Depot Activity or the use by the

of hazardous substances, toxic substances, heavy metals, explosives, pollutants, contaminants, waste or petroleum products, or any combination thereof, regardless of when the contamination is discovered or where it has spread.

text.#text: Neither the Zuni Tribe nor the Navajo Nation shall be liable for any damages resulting from

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: activities on or off the Former Fort Wingate Depot Activity site, or the prior use of hazardous substances, toxic substances, heavy metals, explosives, pollutants, contaminants, waste or petroleum products, or any combination thereof, regardless of when the contamination is discovered or where it has spread.

text.#text: The Zuni Tribe and the Navajo Nation shall be held harmless from any claim, suit, demand, judgment, cost, or fee arising from
